quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There will never be a time like this. I've never seen anything like it. I doubt I'll ever feel anything like this in business again where there's unlimited demand. How do you make sure that three months from now, six months, you have no regrets? Get on the plane to go talk to a customer, make the late night push, check the data six times over again.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A concrete “no regrets” operating playbook for capitalizing on a rare, high-demand market window.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We're the largest expert network in the world. We have this massive strategic advantage, which is like no customer acquisition costs. The only moat in human data is access to an audience.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A clear mental model for defensibility in AI data businesses: distribution/access beats tooling as the moat.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The models have gotten so good that the generalists are no longer needed. What they really need is experts.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A counterintuitive shift in where value comes from as models improve: specialized expert input becomes the bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Four months later, they hit 50 million ARR. They're now on pace to blow past 100 million ARR within just 12 months.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A striking benchmark illustrating the speed at which an AI-adjacent data business can scale when built on an existing network.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: CodeRabbit acts as your AI co-pilot, providing instant code review comments and potential impacts of every pull request.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (CodeRabbit read)
quotes.context: A practical workflow model for speeding up reviews by pairing comments with impact analysis on each PR.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Beyond just flagging issues, CodeRabbit provides one click fix suggestions and lets you define custom code quality rules using AST GREP patterns, catching subtle issues that traditional static analysis tools might miss.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (CodeRabbit read)
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: combine automated fixes with customizable AST-based rules to catch edge cases static analysis misses.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: CodeRabbit has so far reviewed more than 10 million PRs installed on 1 million repositories, and is used by over 70,000 open source projects.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (CodeRabbit read)
quotes.context: Concrete adoption metrics that signal maturity and real-world usage at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Orkes Conductor, you gain an agentic orchestration layer that seamlessly connects humans, AI agents, APIs, microservices, and data pipelines in real time at enterprise scale.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Orkes read)
quotes.context: A systems framework for building agentic workflows by treating orchestration as the connective layer across people, agents, and services.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's not just about automating tasks, it's orchestrating autonomous agents and complex workflows to deliver smarter outcomes faster.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Orkes read)
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that shifts focus from task automation to coordinating autonomous systems for outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: What data labeling is and why it matters
quotes.text: So, there's really two primary functions. There's a pre-training and a post-training process in training a model, and for a long time these AI providers, or LLMs, or Frontier Labs we're focused on basically sucking up more and more information on the pre-training side of the house.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Provides a simple, practitioner-friendly framework for thinking about how frontier models are trained: pre-training vs. post-training.

quotes.topic_title: What data labeling is and why it matters
quotes.text: And about 18 months ago, 24 months ago, we started to really see an asymptoting of gains coming from, because they had essentially sucked up all of the knowledge on the internet. And so, labs really shifted towards most of the gains now coming from the post-training side of the house.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Counterintuitively reframes where progress comes from now—post-training data, not more pre-training scale—because pre-training returns are plateauing.

quotes.topic_title: What data labeling is and why it matters
quotes.text: And what post-training is, is it's augmenting and improving the data they have across every discipline or capability area that they care about.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Actionable definition of post-training that highlights a practical lever: targeted, domain-specific data improvement.

quotes.topic_title: What data labeling is and why it matters
quotes.text: Basically they're running experiments, almost think like the scientific process. They have a hypothesis around how to improve the model. They're trying to collect small pieces of data to see if that hypothesis works out. If that hypothesis is proving true, then they expand the overall collection of the data in that advert.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Offers a concrete methodology for iterating on model improvements: hypothesis-driven experiments with small data pilots that scale only when validated.

quotes.topic_title: What data labeling is and why it matters
quotes.text: It can also be reinforcement learning with human feedback, which is like preference ranking data.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Gives a specific example of what post-training data can look like, grounding the concept in a common frontier technique (RLHF).

quotes.topic_title: Post-training methods: RLHF, SFT, trajectories
quotes.text: I mean, yes and no because take for example trajectories, or you want to be able to do, people use flight search or an accounting end-to-end process, or you want to be able to conduct biological experiments, you need actual trajectory data.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Challenges the simplistic “RLHF vs fine-tuning” framing by emphasizing trajectory data as a distinct, practical requirement for real workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Post-training methods: RLHF, SFT, trajectories
quotes.text: But I think reinforcement learning is really preference ranking, like which question do you like more, question A or question B? SFT data is a prompt and a response, and obviously the labs are very focused on these thinking or reasoning models.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Provides a clear mental model for post-training data types (preference ranking vs prompt-response) and ties it to current lab priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Post-training methods: RLHF, SFT, trajectories
quotes.text: So, in order to improve a reasoning model you need to actually have the step-by-step instructions, of which when you interact with a lot of these frontier models they struggle in very advanced domains.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: if you want better reasoning, collect step-by-step reasoning traces—especially for advanced domains where models fail.

quotes.topic_title: Post-training methods: RLHF, SFT, trajectories
quotes.text: Our real unique proposition as a business is the fact that we have an engaged audience. We have 18 million professionals across, we have 500,000 PhDs, we have 3 million master students, we're a global platform.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Concrete data point showing how scale + expertise distribution can be leveraged to source higher-quality post-training data.

quotes.topic_title: Post-training methods: RLHF, SFT, trajectories
quotes.text: And so, the ability to hyper-target this audience into chemistry, math, physics, biology, coding and really touch parts of human knowledge that have never before made it to the internet is really where we excel.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A methodology for data collection: hyper-target domain experts to access knowledge not captured in public web corpora.

quotes.topic_title: Handshake’s edge: experts over generalists
quotes.text: We have 18 million professionals across, we have 500,000 PhDs, we have 3 million master students, we're a global platform.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Concrete scale metrics that quantify Handshake’s expert-heavy supply and why it can serve specialized AI data needs.

quotes.topic_title: Handshake’s edge: experts over generalists
quotes.text: Defending your thesis means, generally speaking, you have proven that you have extended the world's knowledge in a particular domain.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A crisp definition of “expert” that can be used as a practical bar for sourcing high-signal contributors.

quotes.topic_title: Handshake’s edge: experts over generalists
quotes.text: the ability to hyper-target this audience into chemistry, math, physics, biology, coding and really touch parts of human knowledge that have never before made it to the internet is really where we excel.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A methodology for advancing models: hyper-target domain experts to surface offline/uncaptured knowledge rather than scraping more web data.

quotes.topic_title: Handshake’s edge: experts over generalists
quotes.text: But really what's happened is the models have gotten so good that the generalists are no longer needed. What they really need is experts, experts across every area that the models are focused on.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A contrarian market shift claim practitioners can act on: reallocate labeling budgets from low-cost generalists to domain experts.

quotes.topic_title: Handshake’s edge: experts over generalists
quotes.text: you could think about these model builders as they're focused on the most economically valuable capability areas in the economy.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A prioritization lens for data/labeling strategy: align expert sourcing to the highest economic-value capability areas.

quotes.topic_title: Creating new data and breaking models
quotes.text: Yep. And I also say we help point out where the models are weak.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Frames expert data generation as not just adding knowledge, but systematically diagnosing model failure modes.

quotes.topic_title: Creating new data and breaking models
quotes.text: So, in order to break a model, it's pretty tough for the average person to break a model and get an incorrect response.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Highlights that meaningful model evaluation often requires specialized expertise, not typical user testing.

quotes.topic_title: Creating new data and breaking models
quotes.text: But if you are a PhD in physics, you can go in multiple subdomains of physics and prove where the model's actually breaking, either breaking in its reasoning steps or it's where it's broken in its ground truth right answer, or we start throwing tools in there or needing to follow some step-by-step process.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Provides a concrete methodology for stress-testing models: probe subdomains, audit reasoning vs. ground truth, and introduce tools/stepwise constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Creating new data and breaking models
quotes.text: And I wouldn't say it's easy for them, but the average person cannot break the models and that's where we really come in.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Clarifies the practical moat: even experts find it hard, and expert networks fill the gap in uncovering non-obvious weaknesses.

quotes.topic_title: What experts do day-to-day (GPQA example)
quotes.text: essentially the crux of the paper is you break the model, you provide a ground truth, the right answer to the question, you provide the step-by-step a reasoning steps.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A clear methodology for expert data creation: intentionally stress-test the model, then supply both the correct answer and the reasoning trace.

quotes.topic_title: What experts do day-to-day (GPQA example)
quotes.text: So, you might imagine because models are non-deterministic, the model can get the answer right once, but it might not get the answer right three out of five times. So, you actually prove where the model's failing.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Highlights a practical evaluation lens: reliability across repeated trials matters more than a single correct output, and experts should localize failure modes.

quotes.topic_title: What experts do day-to-day (GPQA example)
quotes.text: Maybe it can get, it knows the question, it can get the right answer, but the actual steps to get there are wrong and they really focus on the steps to get there.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Emphasizes process supervision: improving models requires checking intermediate reasoning, not just final answers.

quotes.topic_title: What experts do day-to-day (GPQA example)
quotes.text: Say there's 10 steps in a math problem, step 6 through 10 is wrong. So, how do you fix the actual steps?
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A concrete debugging heuristic: pinpoint exactly which step range fails to target training data and interventions.

quotes.topic_title: What experts do day-to-day (GPQA example)
quotes.text: PhD students expect to be treated different than a lower cost international labor with a different work expectation.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Operational insight for building expert networks: quality depends on designing workflows and incentives that match expert expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Non-verifiable domains and human tool-use capture
quotes.text: Yeah. I mean, a great example, let's take a non-verifiable domain like education.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Introduces the key framework of “non-verifiable domains” where there isn’t a single right answer, changing how you evaluate and train models.

quotes.topic_title: Non-verifiable domains and human tool-use capture
quotes.text: And so, she is interacting with the state-of-the-art models in educational design.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Concrete example of domain experts stress-testing frontier models against real professional standards rather than toy benchmarks.

quotes.topic_title: Non-verifiable domains and human tool-use capture
quotes.text: there's a bunch of papers out there that basically speak to people narrating over their step-by-step tool use.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Highlights a practical methodology—capturing narrated, step-by-step tool use—to generate training data for real workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Non-verifiable domains and human tool-use capture
quotes.text: So, as they go to solve a problem from start to finish, interact with multiple different service areas, interact with multiple different tools, they're like, there's papers that talk about this, talking over what they're doing, actually following and screen recording where their mouse is going, how they're problem solving.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Describes “trajectory” style data capture (screen + mouse + narration) as a way to teach models multi-tool, end-to-end problem solving.

quotes.topic_title: Non-verifiable domains and human tool-use capture
quotes.text: Yeah. A trajectory is basically just like the entire environment that is collecting what you're doing. So it's your screen, it's your mouse-
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Defines “trajectory” in an operational way practitioners can implement when collecting human demonstration data.

quotes.topic_title: Data formats, multimodal work, and rubric judging
quotes.text: And then, we also have multimodal work like audio, like classifying music and understanding ... We're engaging thousands, or not thousands, probably hundreds of top music students at the music schools in the country who are improving models of understanding of music.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Concrete example of using domain experts (music students) for multimodal labeling to improve model understanding beyond text.

quotes.topic_title: Data formats, multimodal work, and rubric judging
quotes.text: In some of these domains, you actually don't have a guaranteed correct right answer. And so, models can sit in the middle as a judge and actually understand what is ... Think back on your school days. How do you get A on your 5,000 word paper? Well, there's a great introductory statement and there's scientific proof. So, you can build a rubric that allows a model to sit in the middle and actually auto-evaluate responses.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Introduces rubric-based evaluation as a methodology for subjective domains where “correctness” isn’t binary, using models as judges.

quotes.topic_title: Data formats, multimodal work, and rubric judging
quotes.text: They really care about, to zoom out, they care about three things. They care about quality first and foremost. You have to have high quality data.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A simple prioritization framework for data work: quality is the primary constraint before anything else.

quotes.topic_title: Data formats, multimodal work, and rubric judging
quotes.text: And if you imagine you're training a model, like teaching a student and you're giving it the wrong data, it's extremely challenging to overcome that.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Memorable mental model explaining why bad data is costly: it creates learning debt that’s hard to undo.

quotes.topic_title: Data formats, multimodal work, and rubric judging
quotes.text: And then, the other huge problems you have is volume. How do you generate thousands of pieces of data in the most advanced domains of chemistry, and mathematics, and physics, and how do you ensure that it's high quality?
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Highlights the core scaling challenge practitioners face: producing large volumes of expert-grade data without sacrificing quality.

quotes.topic_title: What labs optimize for: quality, volume, speed
quotes.text: They really care about, to zoom out, they care about three things. They care about quality first and foremost.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A simple prioritization framework for what frontier model builders optimize for when sourcing training data.

quotes.topic_title: What labs optimize for: quality, volume, speed
quotes.text: And if you imagine you're training a model, like teaching a student and you're giving it the wrong data, it's extremely challenging to overcome that.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that emphasizes why data quality errors are hard to “fix later” in training.

quotes.topic_title: What labs optimize for: quality, volume, speed
quotes.text: And then, the other huge problems you have is volume. How do you generate thousands of pieces of data in the most advanced domains of chemistry, and mathematics, and physics, and how do you ensure that it's high quality?
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Highlights the core scaling challenge: producing large amounts of expert data without sacrificing quality.

quotes.topic_title: What labs optimize for: quality, volume, speed
quotes.text: And then, the other thing I would say model builders care about is speed, because they have all these hypotheses and they're constantly testing different pipelines.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Connects data operations to research iteration loops—fast turnaround enables rapid hypothesis testing and pipeline selection.

quotes.topic_title: What labs optimize for: quality, volume, speed
quotes.text: So, your ability to quickly turn around for them in a period of days, and then get to high volumes of data that are high quality is the number one thing they care about.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A concrete operational target (days-level turnaround) that practitioners can use to design data production and feedback systems.

quotes.topic_title: Humans in the loop and jobs impact debate
quotes.text: And I think for as long as models are improving, humans will be needed in this process.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A clear rule-of-thumb for practitioners planning human-in-the-loop workflows: as long as model capability is moving, human data creation/feedback remains a durable lever.

quotes.topic_title: Humans in the loop and jobs impact debate
quotes.text: I'm probably in the camp of like GDP growth over universal basic income.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A contrarian framing of the jobs debate that prioritizes productivity-led growth as the primary mechanism for adapting to AI-driven change.

quotes.topic_title: Humans in the loop and jobs impact debate
quotes.text: It's like now one person, one young, talented, AI native, Iron Man suit enabled young person can get on and they can build their own videos, produce their own creative assets, post across multiple social media platforms, run all of their own analytics. They don't need a data science degree to be able to do that.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A concrete example of AI collapsing multi-role workflows into one operator—useful for redesigning team structure, hiring profiles, and tool stacks.

quotes.topic_title: Humans in the loop and jobs impact debate
quotes.text: Or take an intern in our company, he had his first PR up I think the afternoon he started.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A specific productivity datapoint illustrating how AI can compress onboarding time and enable earlier contribution from entry-level hires.

quotes.topic_title: Humans in the loop and jobs impact debate
quotes.text: It's like I think being AI native and having your Iron Man suit on, and understanding how to leverage these tools is like young people are at a huge advantage.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“Iron Man suit”) practitioners can use to emphasize tool leverage as a core competency in training, hiring, and career development.

quotes.topic_title: Market dynamics and Scale’s acquisition implications
quotes.text: for as long as there are problems in solving any problem with AI, any human problem, there will need to be humans in the loop helping advance that.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A durable mental model for why human-in-the-loop data work remains essential even as models improve.

quotes.topic_title: Market dynamics and Scale’s acquisition implications
quotes.text: if you viewed your research team and your model building team, and the experiments they're running to be really the cornerstone of how you're improving, you probably wouldn't want the latest research of what you're trying to work on being invested in by a peer.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Highlights a practical competitive-risk consideration when choosing data/labeling partners tied to rival labs.

quotes.topic_title: Market dynamics and Scale’s acquisition implications
quotes.text: We like to say the only moat in human data is access to an audience.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A crisp framework for competitive advantage in expert data: distribution and trust beat pure spend or ops.

quotes.topic_title: Market dynamics and Scale’s acquisition implications
quotes.text: they're basically running TikTok ads, running Instagram ads, paying money for Google Search display ads, YouTube ads, and they will be like, "Can you get me 200 physics PhDs?"
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Concrete example of how many competitors try (and struggle) to source rare experts via generic paid acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Market dynamics and Scale’s acquisition implications
quotes.text: The huge advantage that we've had and why we've resonated so fast in the marketplace is we built a decade of trust with 18 million people, and they trust us, and we built a ton of brand affinity, and they use Handshake, and they have an active profile, and we have a ton of information around their academic performance and what they've done in school.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Specific moat mechanics (trust + owned audience + rich profiles) that enable faster, higher-quality expert sourcing at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Claude at least 10 times a day.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete usage benchmark that encourages practitioners to embed an AI assistant deeply into daily workflows rather than treating it as occasional tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Just last week I was preparing for an interview with a very fancy guest, and I had Claude tell me what are all the questions that other podcast hosts have asked this guest so that I don't ask them these questions?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific, replicable tactic for using AI to de-duplicate common questions and differentiate interviews (or any customer conversation).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Claude can handle incredibly complex multistep work.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical framing for assigning AI not just single prompts, but end-to-end multi-step synthesis tasks common in product and research work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can throw a 100-page strategy document at it and ask it for insights, or you can dump all your user research and ask it to find patterns.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable methodology for using AI as a synthesis engine across large, messy inputs (strategy docs, research repositories) to extract insights and patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Claude 4 and the new integrations including Claude 4 Opus, the world's best coding model, you get voice conversations, advanced research capabilities, direct Google Workspace integration, and now MCP connections to your custom tools and data sources. Claude just becomes part of your workflow.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A workflow-centric mental model: value comes from integrating AI into existing tools/data so it operates as an always-available collaborator, not a standalone app.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: launching the new AI data business
quotes.text: So, we started to see all what I would call middleman companies reaching out to us saying, "Can we recruit your PhDs and master's students?"
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Shows a repeatable way to spot new product opportunities: watch who tries to access your supply via intermediaries.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: launching the new AI data business
quotes.text: Training was very transactional, it was very amorphous how you could get paid. There was immense amount of drop-off in the process to actual project like completion on these other platforms.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Identifies concrete marketplace failure modes (unclear incentives + drop-off) that practitioners can target to win by improving the end-to-end workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: launching the new AI data business
quotes.text: they started to reach out to us and started to go direct and trying to almost cut out the middleman.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A strong signal of disintermediation: when demand-side players go direct, it often means the intermediary isn’t adding enough value.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: launching the new AI data business
quotes.text: we just believe there will need to be a platform, an experts first platform in the pursuit of ASI and advancing AI, and there will need to be a place that everyone in the world could go to, to monetize their skills and their knowledge as these labs are focused on improving in all these multidisciplinary.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A clear positioning framework: build “experts-first” infrastructure that aligns incentives for specialized contributors in a fast-scaling ecosystem.

quotes.topic_title: Origin story: launching the new AI data business
quotes.text: Fast-forward to today, we're working with seven of the Frontier Labs, basically every lab that's doing work and building the best large language models, and the team has exploded and revenue's exploded, and it's been really a incredible ride running back new company inside of a company for the second time over again.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A concrete scaling example (seven frontier labs) plus the “company inside a company” approach to launching a new line at speed.

quotes.topic_title: Handshake core business and AI-era unfair advantage
quotes.text: It's like the bar has been shifting constantly. A year ago that'd be legendary. Now it's like, all right, well another one of these. 50 million in four months, no big deal. It's truly insane.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete growth benchmark that highlights how quickly “exceptional” traction has become table stakes in the AI era.

quotes.topic_title: Handshake core business and AI-era unfair advantage
quotes.text: It's a verb with young people in America, it's a verb with people that are in college in their PhD or master's program, and it is, I call it an unconnected graph, meaning you don't need to ... LinkedIn is very focused on who you know and what your experience is.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A memorable positioning framework (“unconnected graph”) for building networks that work even when users lack connections or credentials.

quotes.topic_title: Handshake core business and AI-era unfair advantage
quotes.text: I think this is just an interesting time for our people to think about what have we done that may give us a new opportunity to build something huge based on this unfair advantage that we have?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable prompt for practitioners to inventory existing assets and re-leverage them as AI unlocks new product surfaces.

quotes.topic_title: Handshake core business and AI-era unfair advantage
quotes.text: I think also as your company grows in size and headcount, and maturity, it's also hard to incubate something new inside of a business. It's hard in so many ways.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that scale can reduce innovation velocity, implying teams should design explicitly for “second zero-to-one” efforts.

quotes.topic_title: Handshake core business and AI-era unfair advantage
quotes.text: And then yeah, we have this massive strategic advantage, which is no cost or acquisition costs, and we have much higher conversion rates and retention than any of the other platforms by a large margin because we have such consumer affinity.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A practical “unfair advantage” checklist—CAC, conversion, retention, affinity—that can guide strategy and moat assessment.

quotes.topic_title: How expert data platforms recruit and retain talent
quotes.text: I think if you care about building a really high quality business, and having good gross margin and high quality growth, the ecosystem here is, one of the leading players, they have 200 recruiters. It's unsustainable.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A concrete example of why recruiter-heavy expert acquisition doesn’t scale and can structurally hurt margins.

quotes.topic_title: How expert data platforms recruit and retain talent
quotes.text: There are like 200 people on LinkedIn sending individual messages to acquire these people, because there's no brand, there's no trust. They're spending tens of millions of dollars a month on performance advertising, Google Ads-
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Highlights the hidden cost drivers (lack of brand/trust) that force expensive outbound + paid acquisition loops.

quotes.topic_title: How expert data platforms recruit and retain talent
quotes.text: And then they put them onto an experience that is treating them like they're drawing boundary boxes around stop signs in the Philippines. The frontier tax accountants don't want to be treated like low cost international labor, and I don't think anyone enjoys that process.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A memorable framing of why expert retention requires a fundamentally different product experience than commodity labeling.

quotes.topic_title: How expert data platforms recruit and retain talent
quotes.text: So, we can do this thing where we produce one unit of data ourselves. We pay for it, almost like a movie production. We pay for a unit of data, and then we make sure it's very high quality. We run our own post-training on it, and then we produce a bunch of specifications of the data, and we actually sell that individual package of data to many different labs.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Introduces a reusable “data package” production model (invest once, sell many times) that changes unit economics.

quotes.topic_title: How expert data platforms recruit and retain talent
quotes.text: You have a cost to customer acquisition, your CAC, and then you have your LTV, like the lifetime value of a user. And an LTV is calculated pretty simply in this business. It is based on the retention of a person, and how many projects they can participate in.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A simple operational definition of LTV for expert networks that directly ties product experience to economics.

quotes.topic_title: Incubating business two inside business one
quotes.text: Tactically we were working with many of the middleman companies doing work.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Highlights a pragmatic starting point: use intermediaries to get into the workflow and learn the market before going direct.

quotes.topic_title: Incubating business two inside business one
quotes.text: We started to see direct outreach from the Frontier Labs reaching out to us, trying to cut out the middleman in their pursuit of getting higher-quality data.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A clear demand signal: when customers try to bypass intermediaries for quality, it can indicate an opportunity to build a direct offering.

quotes.topic_title: Incubating business two inside business one
quotes.text: When we started to put together the dots on we could build a way better experience for our fellows, we could serve them directly to the labs and build a direct customer relationship with the labs, and basically cut out the middleman.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: A repeatable playbook: connect demand signals to a direct-to-customer model that improves the product and relationship on both sides.

quotes.topic_title: Incubating business two inside business one
quotes.text: And provide a better experience to the labs, provide a better experience to our fellows and provide a better experience to our million companies in the network.
quotes.speaker: Garrett Lord
quotes.context: Emphasizes a multi-sided value proposition—optimize for win-win-win outcomes to justify disintermediation.
